body:
DeflaterOutputStream `finish`: Finishes writing compressed data to the output stream without closing the underlying stream. Use this method when applying multiple filters in succession to the same output stream.

What is the problem?

Hmm, so I can only reproduce this on Android, not desktop. Nexus 7, Android 4.4.4, build KTU84P. This is what happens:

```
W/System.err( 5680): java.io.IOException: attempt to write after finish
W/System.err( 5680):    at java.util.zip.DeflaterOutputStream.write(DeflaterOutputStream.java:172)
W/System.err( 5680):    at java.io.OutputStream.write(OutputStream.java:82)
W/System.err( 5680):    at libcore.io.Streams.writeSingleByte(Streams.java:53)
W/System.err( 5680):    at java.util.zip.DeflaterOutputStream.write(DeflaterOutputStream.java:161)
W/System.err( 5680):    at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.PixmapIO$PNG.write(PixmapIO.java:298)
W/System.err( 5680):    at com.frozenfractal.bigcanvas.PngUtils.toPng(PngUtils.java:21)
W/System.err( 5680):    at com.frozenfractal.bigcanvas.TileManager.sendDelta(TileManager.java:95)
W/System.err( 5680):    at com.frozenfractal.bigcanvas.TileManager.maybeSendDeltas(TileManager.java:79)
W/System.err( 5680):    at com.frozenfractal.bigcanvas.Bigcanvas.render(Bigcanvas.java:111)
W/System.err( 5680):    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.android.AndroidGraphics.onDrawFrame(AndroidGraphics.java:422)
W/System.err( 5680):    at android.opengl.GLSurfaceView$GLThread.guardedRun(GLSurfaceView.java:1523)
W/System.err( 5680):    at android.opengl.GLSurfaceView$GLThread.run(GLSurfaceView.java:1240)
```

I found that phrase [here](https://github.com/google/j2objc/blob/592382e0bf314134fac9bfee862dacca50fccdb1/jre_emul/android/libcore/luni/src/main/java/java/util/zip/DeflaterOutputStream.java#L172), so supposing that code is based on Android sources, this might actually be an Android bug :( If so, let's figure out how libgdx can work around this.
Looks like Android is broken. Want to make a PR that recreates the DeflaterOutputStream if Gdx.app.type is Android?

That's the least I can do for filing crappy bug reports against you :)

Also reported upstream: https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=172620

Hm. As I understand the `#finish()` docs, it only mentions not closing the _underlying_ Stream (i.e. the one passed in e.g. https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/zip/DeflaterOutputStream.html#DeflaterOutputStream%28java.io.OutputStream%29 constructor), not the `this` DOStream itself. The DOS will be (and should be, as per AH tests) invalid for `#write()` after `#finish()`; `PNG.write()` _does_ close the underlying DOS before return though. I think that being able to re-use it in this matter on a desktop is a code artifact at best.

IMO either the libGDX's docs are wrong with regards to class PNG reusability, or the algo is currently implemented in a wrong matter for that to be possible.
That was also my conclusion. I've updated the PR accordingly.

The javadocs don't say it can't be reused and it can be reused on desktop.
We should special case for Android, who seem to have implemented it wrong.

> The javadocs don't say it can't be reused

That's exactly the point. It also doesn't say it _can_ be reused after it - as such, it creates an obvious implementation dependence since it's an artifact, not a guaranteed API feature. Relaying on implementation-dependent behaviour, not guaranteed by API's contract is the easiest way to create WTFs as soon as the underlying lib implementation details change for any reason.

> who seem to have implemented it wrong.

I agree that the docs are ambiguous here, and I agree that `#finish()` _shouldn't_ close the DOS for the convenience of API user - and that AH/Android has taken the inconvenient route here... while e.g. RoboVM goes the same route as JDK source (and docs), Apache Harmony really has the test mentioned http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/harmony/enhanced/archive/classlib/java6/modules/archive/src/test/java/org/apache/harmony/archive/tests/java/util/zip/DeflaterOutputStreamTest.java - with `test_finish()` _explicitly_ requiring the writes to throw an exception after `#finish()`. Without any explicit Oracle JDK doc reference / test suite showing that it indeed _can_ be reused (If somebody has/knows of such info/link/test, I'd be very grateful to see it), we're basing the code on implementation details, not the API itself. It's your call, one way or the other, and I'm not saying that https://code.google.com/u/100542696791565253700/ has to be right on this, because the interpretations may vary. I'm just saying that relaying on UB is always a high risk strategy in my book.

NB I understand that AH is retired etc.; still, disregarding AH stance on this is risky, as it shows that the implementation may (obviously) cause the code to fail on desktop on non-Oracle Java VMs/runtimes, if they went the same road as AH... not to mention that Android lib is based on AH itself.

I would generally interpret a method called `finish` to mean "I am done with this and won't be using it again", so would expect to not be able to use it again. Further, I'd imagine that "minimal allocation" is not a huge requirement when writing images and the creation of a new DeflaterOutputStream is .

Based on discussion here and my agreement that relying on undefined behavior is risky, I'd be in favor of merging the PR without special casing Android.

If a method has a side effect that leaves the object in an unusable state, that _must_ be in the method contract / javadoc. I'd say it is a reasonable assumption, given the rarity and importance of that side effect, that if a method does _not_ specify this that the object is still in a usable state, regardless of the method name. There is no undefined behavior here. The javadocs don't say the object is no longer usable, so an implementation that makes it no longer usable is wrong.

That said, I agree the allocation isn't a big deal. To workaround the poor implementation, I'm fine with not special casing stupid Android. :)
